segment.source: Exercise 3 - Identify Problems with Missing Constraints
segment.target: Exercise 3 - Identify Problems with Missing Constraints

segment.source: The SoC power state is the sum of the states of all the devices.
segment.target: The SoC power state is the sum of the states of all the devices.

segment.source: Exercise 3 - Identify Problems with Missing Constraints
segment.target: Exercise 3 - Identify Problems with Missing Constraints

segment.source: The SoC power state is the sum of the states of all the devices.
segment.target: The SoC power state is the sum of the states of all the devices.

segment.source: Windows keeps a list of devices and their states that are critical to reach low power – they are called constraints.
segment.target: Windows keeps a list of devices and their states that are critical to reach low power – they are called constraints.

segment.source: Windows will wait for all constraints to be met before engaging resiliency and entering DRIPS.
segment.target: Windows will wait for all constraints to be met before engaging resiliency and entering DRIPS.

segment.source: The constraints are specified by an OEM and the SoC vendor through the ACPI firmware.
segment.target: The constraints are specified by an OEM and the SoC vendor through the ACPI firmware.

segment.source: The ACPI firmware must be modified if an OEM changes the SoC vendor reference design and constraints must reflect those changes accurately.
segment.target: The ACPI firmware must be modified if an OEM changes the SoC vendor reference design and constraints must reflect those changes accurately.

segment.source: Missing constraints, or having too many constraints, can cause a variety of problems that increase power drain during standby.
segment.target: Missing constraints, or having too many constraints, can cause a variety of problems that increase power drain during standby.

segment.source: Download the pre-generated sleepstudy-report2.html report here.
segment.target: Download the pre-generated sleepstudy-report2.html report here.

segment.source: Open sleepstudy-report2.html with your favorite browser.
segment.target: Open sleepstudy-report2.html with your favorite browser.

segment.source: Click on Session 12.
segment.target: Click on Session 12.

segment.source: The system consumes 1.307 Watts of energy during 11 minutes
segment.target: The system consumes 1.307 Watts of energy during 11 minutes

segment.source: The DRIPS % is 92%.
segment.target: The DRIPS % is 92%.

segment.source: The hardware DRIPS % is 19%.
segment.target: The hardware DRIPS % is 19%.

segment.source: Look at the Top Offenders table
segment.target: Look at the Top Offenders table

segment.source: The wireless networking device is listed as active only 7% of the time during the session.
segment.target: The wireless networking device is listed as active only 7% of the time during the session.

segment.source: This problem can’t account for the 19% HW DRIPS rate.
segment.target: This problem can’t account for the 19% HW DRIPS rate.

segment.source: Large discrepancies between software DRIPS % (for example, 92%) and hardware DRIPS % (for example, 19%) is usually symptomatic of a missing constraint in the ACPI firmware.
segment.target: Large discrepancies between software DRIPS % (for example, 92%) and hardware DRIPS % (for example, 19%) is usually symptomatic of a missing constraint in the ACPI firmware.

segment.source: Simply stated, Windows assumes the system is ready to enter DRIPS, but some hardware component is still active and prevents the SoC package from entering S0 low power idle.
segment.target: Simply stated, Windows assumes the system is ready to enter DRIPS, but some hardware component is still active and prevents the SoC package from entering S0 low power idle.

segment.source: The next logical step is to try to isolate and identify which hardware component is still in D0 and consuming power by using either a power instrumented platform or your silicon partner debugging tools.
segment.target: The next logical step is to try to isolate and identify which hardware component is still in D0 and consuming power by using either a power instrumented platform or your silicon partner debugging tools.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The missing constraint issue surfaced by the software and hardware DRIPS discrepancy is different than the Wireless device 7% active time problem shown in the top offenders table.
segment.target: The missing constraint issue surfaced by the software and hardware DRIPS discrepancy is different than the Wireless device 7% active time problem shown in the top offenders table.

segment.source: This issue should be investigated separately.
segment.target: This issue should be investigated separately.
